abstracts.cdata!:
The main goals of the regional
            Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System (MBRS) project are to
            facilitate enhanced protection of vulnerable and unique
            marine and coastal ecosystems and to assist the countries of
            Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, and Mexico to strengthen and
            coordinate their national efforts for marine ecosystem
            conservation and sustainable use. In order to mitigate
            potentially negative consequences, this environmental
            assessment (EA) suggests the following be considered for the
            construction and operation of the marine protected areas
            infrastructure: Construction will take place during the dry
            season to reduce potential for rain and storm-related
            erosion/sedimentation and contamination. The construction of
            the siting structures should avoid clearing and/or draining
            of mangroves or wetland areas. The EA suggests avoiding
            excavation/dredging or quarrying of coral rocks and sand,
            especially along coastal headlands, reefs, and seagrass
            areas. Construction techniques will include silt barriers
            and berms to control accelerated erosion and sedimentation
            of nearby wetland, riparian or coastal areas. To avoid
            contamination of the surrounding environment with liquid and
            solid wastes caused by the operation of the facilities, a
            solid waste management plan will be in place at the
            initiation of construction. Any oil, grease or fuel should
            be stored in containers and protected from storms.
